Award.AwardTitle: Real-time Bioreporter Sensor and Therapeutic Effector Loop for Monitoring Physiological Fluctuations

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0853780
Sayler

This research effort focuses on the development of a closed loop sense-and-respond biotherapeutic sensor for thyroid hormone control. With an objective towards biological engineering of "humanized" lux-based bioluminescent bioreporters for autonomous sensing of hyper and hypothyroid states, it is hypothesized that new biophotonic silicon platforms can be fabricated to intelligently diagnosis and respond to health related insults. The intellectual merit of this research advances our understanding of coordinate multi-gene expression in mammalian cell lines and promotes novel strategies for controlling gene expression in mammalian cells using electrical induction. The research has broader impacts and benefits society because it structures a new foundation for future lab-on-chip array sensors for metabolic monitoring in blood, breath, saliva, urine, and perspiration and for applications in in vivo whole-body imaging. The multidisciplinary nature of the research additionally promotes teaching, training, and learning at a level where the boundaries of biology and engineering merge, thus creating a cross-training regimen critical to advancing the biotechnological knowledge of participating graduate and undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Medical theranostics refers to the concept of merging a diagnostic output with a therapeutic input to ensure that a patient receives therapy personalized specifically to his or her disease condition. Diagnostic devices that complement theranostic biotherapies require elements capable of sensing when body systems are out of balance and autonomously responding with appropriate countermeasures. To move toward such a device, this research project focused on the creation of human reporter cells designed to autonomously emit bioluminescent light in real-time when exposed to changing physiological states. This strategy required a synthetic biology approach that re-configured the nucleic acid sequence of the bioluminescent bacterial luciferase (lux) operon to allow it to function in human cells. The advantage of bacterial luciferase over other more common light-generating reporter systems like firefly luciferase is that every component of the bioluminescent reaction is fully provided for by the cell itself, thereby allowing light to be produced continuously with no additions of extraneous substrates or other required manipulations. These characteristics are critical for maintaining these reporter cells as independent sensing elements that could, for example, be implanted within the body to continuously monitor for out-of-range therapeutic states. We have demonstrated such functionality within mouse models and further demonstrated the parallel sensing capabilities of our reporter cells in non-animal cell-based assays. We have also developed an integrated circuit microluminometer that can detect the light signals being produced from reporter cells to create an all-in-one biosensor unit for intelligent (and perhaps implantable) medical surveillance. To form a closed-loop sense-and-respond device, genes capable of being activated by electrical pulses were identified, which may allow the integrated circuit to both sense the light response and react to it via emission of an electrical pulse that activates specific reactive genes within the cell. In such a scenario, it may in future efforts be possible to design a human cell that monitors the body for a specific disease signature and, upon detecting that signature, releases necessary countermeasures to self-remedy that disease state.

This research effort was complemented by educational and outreach activities designed to teach, train, and challenge the next generation of young scientists. Two graduate students performed the bulk of the research with significant contribution from 12 undergraduate students (two of which received supplementary funding through NSF’s Research Experiences for Undergraduate program) and 4 high school students. Twelve publications and 6 book chapters emanated from this work with 5 of our undergraduates achieving publication co-authorships. Nine of our undergraduates have since gone on to advanced degrees or careers in the biomedical or bioengineering fields. Twenty-five percent of our undergraduates originated from groups typically under-represented in the science and engineering disciplines. The ability of cells to emit bioluminescent light was used as unique visual demonstration tools during the University of Tennessee’s Science Fair that catered to 9th through 12th grade students from the Knoxville area as well as within exhibits at several grade school science day presentations.
